titleStmt.title: Gädlä Kiros “Vita of Kiros” / Mälkǝʾa Kiros “Image of Kiros” (II) / Mälkǝʾa Kiros “Image of Kiros” (III)

msItem.title: III. Sälam-hymn to Kiros
msItem.rubric: Nomina sacra; name of the protagonist; name of the original owner (?); groups of lines (alternating with black lines) in the incipit page of Texts I-III; two lines of text (fols. 9va, 10vb, 14vb; reflecting the former text division?); the word hale luya (fol. 23rb); elements of the punctuation signs; elements of Ethiopic numerals. Some words are half rubricated with the first letter(s) written in black ink (e.g., fols. 16va, 21ra, etc.).

span.span: Fols. 50vb: Salutation to you! It was said about you:
(Only one of) your toenail(s) greatly exeeds the weight of the (entire) sky and earth,

p.span: we have entrusted our souls to you, since you were granted the covenant.

div.span: Us, who have assembled to listen to your Vita,
Cover us with your wings like a dove.

p.span: O, God of Kiros, save our father Gäbrä ˀƎgziˀabəḥer fromsuffering of flesh and soul, for ever and ever. Amen, and Amen, so be it, so be it.

msItem.title: II. Mälkǝʾa Kiros “Image of Kiros” (II)
msItem.rubric: Nomina sacra; name of the protagonist; name of the original owner (?); groups of lines (alternating with black lines) in the incipit page of Texts I-III; two lines of text (fols. 9va, 10vb, 14vb; reflecting the former text division?); the word hale luya (fol. 23rb); elements of the punctuation signs; elements of Ethiopic numerals. Some words are half rubricated with the first letter(s) written in black ink (e.g., fols. 16va, 21ra, etc.).

p.span: Fols. 43va: Salutation, salutation while I am beginning the praise of God,

div.span: Who loved your name, and who
I shall recite the praise of your image and the miracle of your greatness,

p.span: Kiros, donate me the treasure of righteousness which shall never go away, Extol the spirit of Ezra Sutuˀel.
Fol.51va: David sang a sweet psalm, with the harp,
: “Precious in the sight of the Lord [is] the death of his saints” (Ps. 115:15).

msItem.title: I. Gädlä Kiros “Vita of Kiros”
msItem.rubric: Nomina sacra; name of the protagonist; name of the original owner (?); groups of lines (alternating with black lines) in the incipit page of Texts I-III; two lines of text (fols. 9va, 10vb, 14vb; reflecting the former text division?); the word hale luya (fol. 23rb); elements of the punctuation signs; elements of Ethiopic numerals. Some words are half rubricated with the first letter(s) written in black ink (e.g., fols. 16va, 21ra, etc.).

p.span: In the name of the Father and the Son and the Holy Spirit, one God. We shall begin with the help of God, we shall write the ascetic life of the holy and blessed father Kiros. Let his prayer and blessing be with his maid, for ever and ever, Amen. And there was on the throne of his father Yonaˀon. And he did the deeds of his father and did not abandon that (duty); and he ruled for 60 years; and he begat a son whose name was ˁAbya. And he died in glory and ˁAbya (sat) on the throne of his father. And he did the deeds of his father and did not abandon that not even once. And the name of his wife (was) Ninasara. And she was infertile for 30 years. And thereafter they prayed together to God and she conceived when (she was) forty

Fol. 33ra: And thereafter came saints and they received the sacraments, father Bawmin and Bäbnuda, father Sämˁon and father Amoy and father Ilarion and father Awnafər and father Lätṣun and father Fauli with all prophets and apostles. The righteous and martyrs and with all angels and the pure and what is in hands of the Saviour, let their prayer and
their entreaty and their intercession be with their servants, for ever and ever, Amen.

note.span: Marrassini (2004:79-81) refers to this version of the Vita of Kiros as the text of “type 1”, most commonly spread and contained in many Mss. It is different from the Vita of “type 2” which is attested in a few Mss. only (translated and published: B. Turaev,
“Kopto-efiopskoe skazanie o prepodobnom Kire”, Zapiski vostočnago otdelenija I
). Marrassini (2004:83) distinguishes two kinds of type 1 Vita of Kiros: “long” and “short”.
The implicit of DMD-013 is even shorter in comparison to the “short” version. The explicit of DMD-013 is similar to Ms.
Comb. 205 and the last part of the explicit (beginning form:

list.item: 8 ፬IV(8; s.l.: 4, stub after 4; 5 stub after 3/fols. 29r-36v)

layout.ab: The upper line is written above the ruling.
The bottom line is written above the ruling.
not always logical (logical in Texts II, III);

list.item: colon with dashes above and below (fol. 18vb, between words: wäy litä ʾale litä; following abbreviations, in fols. 36rb, 37rb, 43rb);
three dot vertical colon which follows the abbreviation for ʿaläm (fol. 5ra);

II. A cross-like sign composed of a vertical red stroke and two red dots on both sides connected by means of thin black lines (used throughout the Ms.; looks like an equivalent for the nine dot asterisk);
Nine dot asterisk (used only three times: fols. 28rb, 38vb, 41rb);
Four dot aterisk (used only in Texts I, II, e.g., fols. 43va, )
III. A chain of four nine dot asterisks connected by means of a chain of black and red dots (fol. 43rb);
A chain of four cross-like signs (s. above) followed by
another four cross-like signs between two chains of black and red dots in the line below (fol. 50va);
Three cross-like signs between two lines composed of one cross-like(s) sign and nine dot asterisks which are connected by means of chains of black and red dots (fols. 51va; 51vb).

decoDesc.decoNote: Fol. 5r (incipit page of Text I): elaborated, uncoloured (black outline) ornamental band with one pair of ailes and two lateral pendants; interlaces, geometric motifs.

span.span: Fol. 51vb: Come to me, being followed by the elders,
To fulfill all desires of my mind.
While entreating the mercy of St. Raphael,
You are the opener of wombs of men and animals,
And your shade raises the dead.

p.span: Fol. 54r: (On) 29 day (of the month) Yäkkatit 57 year of mercy, I, ˀaläqa Bəzuˀayyähu Täwäldä Mädḫən have sold the book “Vita of Our Father Kiros” for thirty Bərr to qes Kahśay Ḥadära. I confirm my selling by writing my signature.

div.span: For this the guarantor is ˀato ˀAṣbəḥa ˁUdar
I, ˀato ˀAṣbəḥa ˁUdar, am the guarantor of the book mentioned above. (I swear; otherwise) may die Haylä Śəllase!
The witnesses who were guarantors for that are

list.item: - Stamp (of the church?): fol. 4r. - Notes and corrections in pencil or pen: fols. 11r, 29r, 35v, 43r, 47rb. - Underlined some words within Text I, referring to the Qal Kidan (the word is written in pen above the lines): fols. 16v, 26v, 36r.

binding.decoNote: Two wooden boards covered with reddish-brown tooled leather. Two pairs of sewing stations.
Two pairs of chains of endband stitches at the spine cover. Folded (not braided) pieces of leather are used for the headband and tailband.

origin.origDate: The Ms. was sold during the reign of Haylä Śǝllase on 29 Yäkkatit 1957 A.M. (= 8th March, 1965 A.D.) (s. Additio 2).

listBibl.bibl: Ms. previously unknown.

projectDesc.p: Encoded according to TEI P5 Guidelines.

person.persName: The book was probably donated by priest Kahsay Ḥadära (s. Additio 2). Gädlä Kiros (fol. 34vb) and Mälkǝʾa Kiros (II) (fol. 51va) contain a supplication prayer for ʾabunä Gäbrä ʾƎgziʾabǝḥer. The remaining supplication formulas have a blank space to accomodate a name.

revisionDesc.change: transformed from mycore to TEI P5
